notes.note:
CC: Left-sided weakness and speech difficulty

HPI: 68 yo male with HTN, DM2, and hyperlipidemia brought in by EMS for sudden onset left-sided weakness and slurred speech. Patient was in his usual state of health until approximately 2 hours ago when his wife noticed he had difficulty speaking and could not move his left arm. Last known well at 10:30 AM per wife who was with him at breakfast. No recent trauma, no preceding headache, no seizure activity witnessed.

PMH: HTN, DM2, Hyperlipidemia, CAD s/p stent 2018
Medications: Lisinopril, Metformin, Atorvastatin, Aspirin 81mg
Allergies: NKDA

Vitals: BP 178/96, HR 88, RR 16, Temp 98.4, O2 Sat 97% RA

Physical Exam:
General: Alert, appears distressed, oriented to person only
HEENT: Pupils equal and reactive, no nystagmus
Cardiac: RRR, no murmurs
Pulm: Clear bilaterally

Neurological Exam:
- Mental Status: Alert, oriented to person only, follows simple commands
- Speech: Dysarthric, paraphasic errors noted, difficulty with repetition
- Cranial Nerves: Left facial droop, central pattern. EOM intact.
- Motor: Right upper/lower extremity 5/5. Left upper extremity 1/5, left lower extremity 2/5
- Sensory: Decreased sensation to light touch left side
- Coordination: Unable to assess left side, right side intact

Assessment: Acute neurological deficit concerning for ischemic stroke in right MCA territory. Within tPA window.

CC: Vertigo, diplopia, ataxia

HPI: 72 yo female with afib on aspirin (not anticoagulated due to falls) presents with sudden onset vertigo, double vision, and difficulty walking that started 90 minutes ago. She was watching TV when symptoms began suddenly. Denies hearing loss, tinnitus, or recent URI. Last known well at 2:00 PM. Family called 911 when she could not stand up from her chair.

PMH: Atrial fibrillation, Hypertension, Osteoporosis with prior falls
Medications: Aspirin 325mg, Amlodipine, Calcium/Vitamin D
Allergies: Penicillin - rash

Vitals: BP 192/98, HR 76 irregular, RR 14, Temp 98.1, O2 Sat 98% RA

Physical Exam:
General: Elderly female, appears uncomfortable, lying still
Cardiac: Irregularly irregular, no murmurs
Pulm: Clear

Neurological Exam:
- Mental Status: Alert and oriented x3, speech fluent without dysarthria
- Cranial Nerves: Vertical and horizontal nystagmus present. Diplopia on left lateral gaze. No facial asymmetry.
- Motor: 4/5 bilateral lower extremities, 5/5 upper extremities
- Sensory: Intact to light touch throughout
- Coordination: Severe truncal and appendicular ataxia. Dysmetria on finger-nose-finger bilaterally. Unable to walk.

Assessment: Acute onset vertigo with diplopia and ataxia concerning for posterior circulation stroke. Patient in afib, high stroke risk. Urgent CT/CTA head and neck.

CC: Resolved speech difficulty

HPI: 58 yo female with HTN, smoking history presents with episode of speech difficulty that resolved. Patient was at work approximately 4 hours ago when she suddenly could not get words out. She knew what she wanted to say but could not speak. Episode lasted approximately 20 minutes then completely resolved. Co-worker witnessed the event and said she looked confused. No weakness, no visual changes, no headache. Patient drove herself to ED after symptoms resolved. Last normal at 10:00 AM.

PMH: Hypertension, 30 pack-year smoking history (still smoking)
Medications: HCTZ
Allergies: NKDA

Vitals: BP 156/92, HR 78, RR 14, Temp 98.6, O2 Sat 99% RA

Physical Exam:
General: Well-appearing, NAD
Cardiac: RRR, no murmurs
Pulm: Clear

Neurological Exam:
- Mental Status: Alert, oriented x3, following commands appropriately
- Speech: Currently fluent, naming intact, repetition intact, no paraphasic errors
- Cranial Nerves: PERRL, EOMI, no facial asymmetry, tongue midline
- Motor: 5/5 all extremities
- Sensory: Intact throughout
- Coordination: Normal finger-nose-finger, rapid alternating movements intact

Assessment: Resolved expressive aphasia, concerning for TIA. High risk features: age, HTN, smoking, symptom duration >10 min. Plan for admission, MRI with DWI, vessel imaging, echo.

CC: Sudden severe headache and right-sided weakness

HPI: 75 yo male with longstanding poorly controlled HTN, on warfarin for mechanical AVR, presents with sudden onset severe headache described as worst of life starting 1 hour ago, followed by progressive right-sided weakness. Patient was sitting in chair when headache began suddenly, then wife noticed right arm became weak. Now with decreased responsiveness. Last known well at 3:00 PM. INR was 3.8 three weeks ago per wife.

PMH: HTN (often non-compliant), Mechanical AVR 2015
Medications: Warfarin, Lisinopril (often doesn't take)
Allergies: NKDA

Vitals: BP 228/118, HR 92, RR 18, Temp 98.2, O2 Sat 96% RA

Physical Exam:
General: Drowsy, arousable to voice, following simple commands only
Cardiac: Mechanical click heard, RRR
Pulm: Clear

Neurological Exam:
- Mental Status: Drowsy, oriented to person only, follows simple one-step commands
- Speech: Slow, dysarthric
- Cranial Nerves: Pupils 4mm bilaterally reactive, R sided facial droop. Gaze preference to left.
- Motor: Left side 5/5, Right arm 0/5, Right leg 2/5
- Sensory: Withdraws on left, minimal response on right

Assessment: Acute presentation concerning for hemorrhagic stroke given sudden onset, severe headache, on anticoagulation with supratherapeutic INR, severe hypertension. STAT CT head. Stroke code activated. Hold anticoagulation, prepare for reversal.

CC: Right hand clumsiness and slurred speech

HPI: 64 yo female with DM2, HTN presents with 3 hours of progressive right hand weakness and slurred speech. Patient first noticed difficulty typing at computer at work. Initially thought it was fatigue but symptoms progressed. Now has difficulty gripping objects and speech is slurred. No headache, no vision changes, no confusion. Denies any sensory symptoms. Last normal this morning at 8 AM.

PMH: DM2 x 15 years, HTN, Obesity
Medications: Metformin, Glipizide, Lisinopril, Atorvastatin
Allergies: Sulfa - hives

Vitals: BP 168/94, HR 82, RR 14, Temp 98.4, O2 Sat 98% RA

Physical Exam:
General: Obese female, uncomfortable but alert
Cardiac: RRR, no murmurs
Pulm: Clear

Neurological Exam:
- Mental Status: Alert, oriented x3, appropriate
- Speech: Dysarthric, but language functions intact
- Cranial Nerves: Mild right lower facial weakness. PERRL, EOMI.
- Motor: Left side 5/5. Right grip 3/5, right arm proximally 4/5, right leg 5/5
- Sensory: Intact to light touch throughout
- Coordination: Dysmetria right hand on FNF testing

Assessment: Pure motor hemiparesis with dysarthria, classic lacunar syndrome. Likely small vessel ischemic stroke. Within treatment window, tPA candidate pending imaging.

CC: Right-sided weakness and speech difficulty

HPI: 34 yo female with long history of migraine with aura presents with right arm tingling that progressed to weakness over 30 minutes, along with word-finding difficulty. Patient reports this started with her typical visual aura - zigzag lines in right visual field. She has had similar episodes before but not this severe. Usually her auras resolve and are followed by headache. Currently has building right-sided headache. No fever, no recent illness. Her migraines usually occur around her menstrual period and she started her period yesterday. Last migraine with aura was 2 months ago.

PMH: Migraine with aura since age 16, typically 2-3 per year
Medications: Sumatriptan PRN, OCP
Allergies: NKDA

Vitals: BP 122/78, HR 72, RR 14, Temp 98.4, O2 Sat 99% RA

Physical Exam:
General: Young female, appears uncomfortable, photophobic
Cardiac: RRR
Pulm: Clear

Neurological Exam:
- Mental Status: Alert, oriented x3, anxious about symptoms
- Speech: Mild word-finding difficulty, pauses in speech
- Cranial Nerves: PERRL, EOMI, no facial asymmetry
- Motor: 4+/5 right upper extremity, 5/5 all other extremities. Drift testing equivocal.
- Sensory: Paresthesias right arm, migrating pattern
- Coordination: Intact

Assessment: Hemiplegic migraine versus complex migraine with prolonged aura. History strongly suggestive of migraine variant. Symptoms migratory and progressive over 30 min (not sudden). Will observe, supportive care, low threshold for imaging if not improving.

CC: Left-sided weakness

HPI: 45 yo male with epilepsy brought in by EMS for left-sided weakness. Per EMS, patient was found on floor by roommate. Roommate reports patient was last normal 1 hour ago, then heard a thump and found patient on floor, confused, with left arm and leg not moving. Roommate reports patient has seizures occasionally and this looked like his post-seizure state. Patient bit his tongue. Bladder incontinence noted at scene. Patient now slowly becoming more alert but still confused. Patient ran out of Keppra 3 days ago.

PMH: Epilepsy since childhood, last seizure 6 months ago
Medications: Levetiracetam 1000mg BID (ran out)
Allergies: NKDA

Vitals: BP 145/88, HR 102, RR 18, Temp 99.1, O2 Sat 96% RA

Physical Exam:
General: Confused, becoming more alert, tongue laceration visible
Cardiac: Tachycardic, regular
Pulm: Clear

Neurological Exam:
- Mental Status: Confused, oriented to person only, slowly improving over exam
- Speech: Slow, dysarthric, improving
- Cranial Nerves: Left facial droop noted. Pupils equal and reactive.
- Motor: Right side 5/5. Left arm 2/5, left leg 3/5.
- Sensory: Difficult to assess given confusion

Assessment: Left hemiparesis in setting of witnessed seizure activity (per surroundings) and medication non-compliance. Clinical picture consistent with postictal Todd's paralysis. Symptoms gradually improving during observation. Will reload Keppra, observe for resolution, low threshold for imaging if not improving as expected.

CC: Confusion and right-sided weakness

HPI: 71 yo male with insulin-dependent DM2 presents with confusion and right-sided weakness. Wife reports patient took his morning insulin but did not eat breakfast. She found him sitting in chair, confused, and noticed his right hand was limp. EMS checked glucose at scene: 38 mg/dL. Given D50 by EMS with rapid improvement in mental status. Glucose now 142 per EMS. Patient now alert and moving all extremities but still feels weak. Denies any other symptoms now.

PMH: DM2 on insulin, CKD stage 3, HTN
Medications: Insulin glargine/lispro, Lisinopril, Amlodipine
Allergies: NKDA

Vitals: BP 138/82, HR 88, RR 14, Temp 98.2, O2 Sat 98% RA

Physical Exam:
General: Elderly male, now alert and conversant, hungry
Cardiac: RRR
Pulm: Clear

Neurological Exam:
- Mental Status: Alert, oriented x3, back to baseline per wife
- Speech: Normal, fluent
- Cranial Nerves: PERRL, EOMI, no facial asymmetry now
- Motor: 5/5 throughout, no drift
- Sensory: Intact
- Coordination: Normal

Assessment: Symptomatic hypoglycemia with neuroglycopenic symptoms including focal weakness, resolved with glucose correction. No residual focal deficits. Will monitor glucose, educate on insulin-meal timing, consider endocrine follow-up.

CC: Whole left side not working

HPI: 28 yo female presents with complete left sided paralysis starting this morning. Patient reports she woke up and entire left side was paralyzed, cannot move at all. Episode started after an argument with boyfriend last night. Patient appears unconcerned about symptoms (la belle indifference). Reports no sensation on entire left side including face. Denies headache, speech difficulty, vision changes. No medical history. Similar episode 2 years ago which resolved after a few hours.

PMH: Anxiety, Depression, Prior episode of similar weakness
Medications: Sertraline
Allergies: NKDA

Vitals: BP 118/72, HR 78, RR 14, Temp 98.4, O2 Sat 99% RA

Physical Exam:
General: Young female, calm, appears unconcerned about paralysis
Cardiac: RRR
Pulm: Clear

Neurological Exam:
- Mental Status: Alert, oriented x3, affect somewhat flat
- Speech: Normal
- Cranial Nerves: Reports cannot see from left eye at all, but blink to threat present. Reports complete left face numbness extending to hairline with sharp midline demarcation.
- Motor: Reports 0/5 entire left side. However, Hoover sign positive. Hip abductor sign positive. When distracted, moves left leg.
- Sensory: Reports complete anesthesia left side with exact midline split, vibratory sense also reported absent left forehead.
- Coordination: Unable to assess left, right side normal

Assessment: Functional neurological disorder / conversion disorder. Multiple positive signs (Hoover, inconsistent exam, non-anatomic sensory loss, la belle indifference, secondary gain context). Recommend supportive approach, neurology consult, psychiatric evaluation.

CC: Face drooping

HPI: 52 yo male presents with left facial drooping noticed this morning. Patient looked in mirror and noticed left side of face was drooping. Cannot close left eye completely, cannot raise left eyebrow, food falling from left side of mouth. Also reports decreased taste on left side of tongue and sounds seem louder in left ear. Symptoms started overnight, first noticed on waking. Denies any limb weakness, numbness, speech difficulty, vision changes. Had a cold last week that resolved.

PMH: Prediabetes
Medications: None
Allergies: NKDA

Vitals: BP 128/78, HR 72, RR 14, Temp 98.4, O2 Sat 99% RA

Physical Exam:
General: Middle-aged male, anxious about facial appearance
Cardiac: RRR
Pulm: Clear

Neurological Exam:
- Mental Status: Alert, oriented x3, worried
- Speech: Slightly muffled but no dysarthria, language intact
- Cranial Nerves: LEFT facial weakness involving entire left face including forehead (cannot raise eyebrow, cannot close eye completely, flattened nasolabial fold). Cannot puff cheek on left. Right face normal. PERRL, EOMI. No nystagmus.
- Motor: 5/5 all extremities, no drift
- Sensory: Intact throughout
- Coordination: Normal

Assessment: Left lower motor neuron facial palsy consistent with Bell's palsy. Key features: forehead involvement, recent viral illness, hyperacusis, taste changes. No upper motor neuron signs, no limb weakness. Start prednisone, eye protection, outpatient follow-up.

CC: Room spinning, nausea, cannot walk

HPI: 48 yo female presents with severe vertigo starting yesterday. Reports room spinning continuously, worse with any head movement. Severe nausea with multiple episodes of vomiting. Cannot walk due to imbalance. Symptoms started gradually yesterday afternoon. Had upper respiratory infection last week. Denies hearing loss, tinnitus, headache, focal weakness, numbness. Denies any history of similar episodes.

PMH: None
Medications: None
Allergies: NKDA

Vitals: BP 132/78, HR 88, RR 16, Temp 98.6, O2 Sat 98% RA

Physical Exam:
General: Female lying still with eyes closed, reluctant to move head
Cardiac: RRR
Pulm: Clear

Neurological Exam:
- Mental Status: Alert, oriented x3
- Speech: Normal
- Cranial Nerves: Horizontal nystagmus present, unidirectional, fast phase to right, suppresses with fixation. No vertical nystagmus. No skew deviation. Hearing grossly intact bilaterally. No facial asymmetry.
- Motor: 5/5 all extremities, no drift
- Sensory: Intact
- Coordination: Dysdiadochokinesia absent. Finger-nose-finger intact but patient nauseated with movement. Gait: Unable to walk independently, veers to left.
- HINTS Exam: Unidirectional nystagmus (horizontal), normal VOR (head impulse test positive to left), no skew

Assessment: Peripheral vestibular syndrome, likely vestibular neuritis given recent viral illness. HINTS exam reassuring for peripheral etiology. No brainstem signs. Supportive care, vestibular suppressants, PCP follow-up.

CC: Left-sided weakness noticed on waking

HPI: 77 yo male with HTN, Afib on apixaban presents with left-sided weakness. Patient went to bed at 11 PM last night in his usual state of health. Wife found him this morning at 6 AM unable to get out of bed, with left arm and leg weakness. Last known well at 11 PM (7 hours ago). Patient cannot recall any symptoms overnight. Denies headache, no seizure activity, no recent falls.

PMH: Afib, HTN, HLD
Medications: Apixaban 5mg BID (last dose last night), Metoprolol, Lisinopril, Atorvastatin
Allergies: NKDA

Vitals: BP 166/92, HR 78 irregular, RR 16, Temp 98.2, O2 Sat 97% RA

Physical Exam:
General: Elderly male, appears frustrated
Cardiac: Irregularly irregular
Pulm: Clear

Neurological Exam:
- Mental Status: Alert, oriented x3
- Speech: Mild dysarthria, language intact
- Cranial Nerves: Left facial droop, central pattern. PERRL, EOMI.
- Motor: Right 5/5. Left arm 2/5, left leg 3/5.
- Sensory: Decreased light touch left side
- Coordination: Unable to assess left, drift present

Assessment: Wake-up stroke, last known well 7 hours ago. Outside standard tPA window but may be candidate for mechanical thrombectomy depending on imaging. On DOAC, need to determine eligibility. Stroke code, STAT CT/CTA, consider MRI perfusion.

CC: Cannot speak

HPI: 82 yo female brought by family for inability to speak. Family reports patient was speaking normally at lunch (12:30 PM), then found 30 minutes later unable to say any words but appeared to understand them. Patient looks frustrated when trying to speak. No weakness noted by family. No headache, no seizure, no recent illness. Last known well 12:30 PM (approximately 2 hours ago).

PMH: HTN, HLD, DM2, Prior TIA 5 years ago
Medications: Aspirin, Lisinopril, Metformin, Rosuvastatin
Allergies: Codeine - nausea

Vitals: BP 172/88, HR 84, RR 14, Temp 98.4, O2 Sat 98% RA

Physical Exam:
General: Elderly female, appears frustrated, cooperative
Cardiac: RRR
Pulm: Clear

Neurological Exam:
- Mental Status: Alert, appears to understand, frustrated
- Speech: Global aphasia - no verbal output, only grunts. Unable to name, repeat, or follow complex commands. Can follow simple one-step commands.
- Cranial Nerves: No facial asymmetry. PERRL, EOMI.
- Motor: 5/5 bilateral upper and lower extremities, no drift
- Sensory: Intact to light touch
- Coordination: Intact

Assessment: Acute onset aphasia without motor deficit, concerning for dominant hemisphere ischemic stroke. Within tPA window. Stroke code activated. STAT CT, tPA candidate if no contraindications.

CC: Confusion and headache

HPI: 55 yo male with poorly controlled HTN presents with confusion and severe headache. Wife reports patient complained of worst headache of his life starting 4 hours ago, then became increasingly confused. Patient is not following commands appropriately. Has been off his BP medications for 2 weeks because ran out and did not refill. Also reports blurry vision. Denies focal weakness per wife. No seizure activity.

PMH: HTN (poorly controlled), CKD stage 3
Medications: Amlodipine, Lisinopril (both ran out 2 weeks ago)
Allergies: NKDA

Vitals: BP 248/142, HR 96, RR 18, Temp 98.4, O2 Sat 97% RA

Physical Exam:
General: Confused male, uncomfortable
Cardiac: S4 gallop, no murmurs
Pulm: Fine crackles at bases

Neurological Exam:
- Mental Status: Confused, oriented to person only, inattentive
- Speech: Slow but no dysarthria or aphasia
- Cranial Nerves: Fundoscopic exam shows papilledema bilaterally. PERRL. No facial asymmetry.
- Motor: Moving all extremities equally, follows commands variably - 4/5 diffusely when cooperative
- Sensory: Difficult to assess
- Coordination: Cannot assess reliably

Assessment: Hypertensive emergency with encephalopathy. Papilledema concerning for increased ICP. No focal deficits on exam. CT head to rule out hemorrhage, then controlled BP reduction. Consider posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES).

CC: Acting strange, left side weak

HPI: 24 yo male brought by friends for altered mental status and possible left-sided weakness. Friends report patient smoked something at a party approximately 2 hours ago (unknown substance, likely synthetic cannabinoid per friends). Shortly after, patient became unresponsive, then agitated, and friends noticed he was not moving his left arm. Patient currently mumbling incoherently. No medical history. No prescribed medications.

PMH: None
Medications: None
Allergies: Unknown

Vitals: BP 158/92, HR 118, RR 20, Temp 99.8, O2 Sat 96% RA

Physical Exam:
General: Young male, agitated, diaphoretic
Cardiac: Tachycardic, regular
Pulm: Clear

Neurological Exam:
- Mental Status: Altered, intermittently follows commands, agitated
- Speech: Incoherent mumbling
- Cranial Nerves: Pupils 5mm bilaterally, reactive. Conjugate gaze. Variable facial movements.
- Motor: Intermittently moves left side, inconsistent exam. Withdraws to pain all extremities.
- Sensory: Withdraws to pain
- Coordination: Unable to assess

Assessment: Acute toxic encephalopathy, likely synthetic cannabinoid intoxication given history. Exam fluctuating and inconsistent with fixed deficit. Tachycardia, hyperthermia support toxicologic etiology. Will obtain CT head to evaluate, tox screen, supportive care. Less likely primary stroke given age and context.

CC: Sudden right-sided weakness and numbness

HPI: 38 yo female with no significant PMH presents with sudden onset right arm and leg weakness with numbness that started 45 minutes ago. Patient was at work when she suddenly felt her right arm go weak and numb, spread to right leg within seconds. Currently cannot lift right arm. Also has mild headache, no vision changes, no speech problems. Recently started oral contraceptives 2 months ago. Smokes 1 pack per day. Family history of mother with DVT.

PMH: None
Medications: OCP (combined)
Allergies: NKDA

Vitals: BP 142/88, HR 76, RR 14, Temp 98.4, O2 Sat 99% RA

Physical Exam:
General: Young female, anxious, holding right arm
Cardiac: RRR, no murmurs, no click
Pulm: Clear

Neurological Exam:
- Mental Status: Alert, oriented x3, anxious but appropriate
- Speech: Normal, fluent
- Cranial Nerves: No facial weakness. PERRL, EOMI.
- Motor: Left 5/5 throughout. Right arm 1/5, right leg 3/5.
- Sensory: Decreased light touch and pinprick entire right side
- Coordination: Unable to assess right side

Assessment: Sudden onset right hemiparesis and hemisensory loss in young patient, highly concerning for stroke despite age. Risk factors: smoking, OCP. Need to evaluate for unusual stroke etiologies (dissection, PFO, hypercoagulable state). Within tPA window - stroke code activated, STAT CT/CTA head and neck.

CC: Confusion, shaking, seeing things

HPI: 58 yo male with history of alcohol abuse presents with confusion, tremors, and visual hallucinations. Patient drinks 1 pint of vodka daily, last drink was 2 days ago when he ran out of money. Since then has had progressive tremors, sweating, and now seeing bugs on the walls. Found by neighbor, confused and shaking. Neighbor reports patient sometimes has shaking episodes after stopping drinking. Exam limited by agitation.

PMH: Alcohol use disorder, prior withdrawal seizures, Liver cirrhosis
Medications: None
Allergies: NKDA

Vitals: BP 168/102, HR 112, RR 20, Temp 100.8, O2 Sat 96% RA

Physical Exam:
General: Agitated, diaphoretic, tremulous
Cardiac: Tachycardic, regular
Pulm: Clear
Abdomen: Distended, fluid wave present

Neurological Exam:
- Mental Status: Confused, disoriented to time and place, visual hallucinations
- Speech: Dysarthric, tangential
- Cranial Nerves: Pupils 4mm reactive, no nystagmus, face symmetric
- Motor: Moving all extremities, significant tremor, appears symmetric
- Sensory: Difficult to assess
- Coordination: Intentional tremor obscures testing

Assessment: Alcohol withdrawal syndrome with delirium tremens given timeline, vital sign abnormalities, hallucinations, and tremor. CIWA protocol, benzodiazepines, thiamine. CT head to rule out other pathology. No focal deficits suggesting stroke.

CC: Sudden vertigo and vomiting, cannot walk

HPI: 69 yo male with HTN, DM2 presents with sudden onset vertigo, nausea, vomiting, and inability to walk starting 2 hours ago. Patient reports room was spinning suddenly while watching TV, immediately felt nauseous and vomited multiple times. When he tried to stand, he fell to the left. Denies headache, weakness, numbness, speech changes. No hearing changes. No recent illness. Last normal 2 hours ago watching TV.

PMH: HTN, DM2, HLD
Medications: Lisinopril, Metformin, Simvastatin
Allergies: NKDA

Vitals: BP 188/98, HR 82, RR 16, Temp 98.4, O2 Sat 97% RA

Physical Exam:
General: Male lying still, eyes closed, vomiting
Cardiac: RRR
Pulm: Clear

Neurological Exam:
- Mental Status: Alert, oriented x3
- Speech: Mildly slurred but language intact
- Cranial Nerves: HINTS exam concerning: Direction-changing nystagmus on lateral gaze. Head impulse test NEGATIVE (abnormal - suggests central). No skew deviation. No facial asymmetry.
- Motor: 5/5 all extremities
- Sensory: Intact
- Coordination: Severe left-sided dysmetria on FNF. Truncal ataxia, falls to left.
- Gait: Unable, severe ataxia

Assessment: Acute vestibular syndrome with central features on HINTS exam (negative head impulse, direction-changing nystagmus) - concerning for cerebellar stroke. STAT CT/CTA, stroke code. High risk for herniation if cerebellar edema develops.

CC: Right-sided weakness and headache

HPI: 22 yo female with history of hemiplegic migraine presents with right arm weakness and severe left-sided headache. Patient has had multiple similar episodes since age 16, diagnosed with hemiplegic migraine. Symptoms started 4 hours ago with visual sparkles in right field, followed by tingling in right hand that spread up arm over 20 minutes, then right arm weakness developed, and now severe throbbing left headache with photophobia and nausea. Her typical hemiplegic migraines follow same pattern and resolve in 24-48 hours.

PMH: Hemiplegic migraine (confirmed by neurologist, MRI previously normal)
Medications: Propranolol prophylaxis, Ketorolac for acute
Allergies: NKDA

Vitals: BP 118/72, HR 68, RR 14, Temp 98.4, O2 Sat 99% RA

Physical Exam:
General: Young female, lying in dark room, ice pack on head
Cardiac: RRR
Pulm: Clear

Neurological Exam:
- Mental Status: Alert, oriented, photophobic
- Speech: Normal
- Cranial Nerves: PERRL (slowly reactive), EOMI, no facial asymmetry
- Motor: Left 5/5. Right arm 3/5, right leg 4/5.
- Sensory: Decreased sensation right arm
- Coordination: Dysmetria right hand

Assessment: Hemiplegic migraine, current episode consistent with prior episodes. Gradual symptom spread (vs sudden in stroke), known diagnosis, typical aura followed by headache. Supportive care, IV ketorolac, antiemetics, dark room. No imaging needed given classic presentation and established diagnosis.

notes.diagnosis: Acute MCA Stroke with tPA Contraindication
notes.note:
CC: Right-sided weakness and speech difficulty

HPI: 78 yo male with Afib on Coumadin presents with sudden right-sided weakness and inability to speak. Family reports patient was fine at dinner at 6 PM, then at 7 PM found unable to move right side and not speaking coherently. Last known well 6 PM (2 hours ago). Patient had GI bleeding 2 weeks ago requiring hospitalization. INR last checked yesterday at anticoagulation clinic was 2.8.

PMH: Afib, CHF, Recent upper GI bleed (2 weeks ago), CKD
Medications: Warfarin, Furosemide, Metoprolol, Omeprazole
Allergies: NKDA

Vitals: BP 178/94, HR 88 irregular, RR 18, Temp 98.4, O2 Sat 96% RA

Physical Exam:
General: Elderly male, eyes deviated to left, not following commands
Cardiac: Irregularly irregular
Pulm: Bibasilar crackles

Neurological Exam:
- Mental Status: Not following commands, appears awake
- Speech: No verbal output, global aphasia
- Cranial Nerves: Eyes deviated to left (left gaze preference). Right facial droop. Pupils 3mm reactive.
- Motor: Left side 5/5, Right arm 0/5, Right leg 1/5.
- Sensory: No response to pain right side

Assessment: Acute left MCA stroke with severe deficit (right hemiplegia, global aphasia, gaze preference). However, tPA CONTRAINDICATED due to: (1) therapeutic INR on Coumadin, (2) recent GI bleeding within 3 weeks. Consider mechanical thrombectomy if large vessel occlusion on CTA. Stroke code activated, STAT CT/CTA.
